thesis.description: During the last few years the possibilities of alcohol as a fuel for internal combustion motors have been brought before the manufacturers and owners of motors on many occasions. Gasoline, the fuel in common use at the present time, while now a fairly cheap and efficient fuel, may and probably will in the near future advance considerably in price. [...]
thesis.creator: Guillet, George L.
thesis.subject: Mechanical Engineering.
thesis.title: The use of alcohol in an internal combustion engine: a comparative series of tests on a Blackstone oil engine using alcohol and coal oil.

thesis.description: A feature of the geology of the vicinity of Montreal and one noted early in the history of the geological exploration of the district, is the occurrence in several places of a remarkable breccia conglomerate. The occurrences are in isolated patches confined to a certain limited belt, and nothing else at all similar is known within a considerable distance. [...]

thesis.title: On the origin and relations of palaeozoic breccia of the vicinity of Montreal.

thesis.description: Théophile Gautier was the most perfect French stylist of his time and perhaps of all time. His pen could mark the most imperceptible shades of meaning with absolute perfection, and no other knew, as he, how to say precisely what he wished to say. [...]

thesis.description: The relation between the chemical composition and heat, or mechanical treatment on the one hand and the microscopic structure on the other, is dealt with at some length in the description of the photomicrographs. thesis.description: When solids are heated they generally pass into a liquid and then into a gaseous state. Solids may, however, pass directly into a gaseous state without apparently passing through the intermediate stage, that is to say, solids evaporate. It is an established fact that ice and snow gradually disappear, and in the Artic regions where the temperature is always below 0°C, this is the only manner in which evaporation can occur. The process is termed sublimation. [...]
thesis.creator: Vipond, William Stanley.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The evaportion of ice.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The fact that an insulated body, charged with electricity, loses its charge when surrounded by a gas in a normal condition has long baen known. In closed vessels this loss of charge is very small. Many theories have been advanced in explanation of the phenomena, but it is now fully established that ionization of a gas makes it a conductor of electricity. [...]

thesis.title: Penetrating radiations and the ionization of the atmosphere.

thesis.description: The object of the experiments performed was to determine the chief physical values and constituents of so-called "CanadianTurpentine", that is, the turpentine obtained from the stumps and roots of pine trees left by the lumbermen. thesis.description: When a conducting substance, such as a copper plate, is,moved through a magnetic field, eddy currents are set up in it, tending to prevent the motion. A somewhat similar effect might be expected in the case of a liquid conductor, though in this case the conditions are not quite the same. In the case of the solid all the particles move at the same velocity, while in the case of the liquid this is not so. [...]
thesis.creator: Dickieson, Arthur L.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: Flow of mercury in a magnetic field.

thesis.description: It is the purpose of this paper to take up in detail the design of some concrete structures which have been greatly developed during the last few years. [...]

thesis.description: The critical study of the resin passages of the Coniferae was suggested by Prof. D. P. Penhallow as a subject presenting many apparent points of similarity, especially in regard to the appearance of thyloses, and resulted in the investigations detailed in the following pages. At the very outset, however, it may be stated that, although the phenomenon of thyloses was observed to exhibit the same characters and to follow the same general rules as in the Pteridophyta, the canals were found to be structures of an entirely different order, not only as regards their function, but also with reference to their mode of development. [...]
thesis.creator: Kirsch, Simon.
thesis.subject: Botony.
thesis.title: The origin and development of resin canals in the coniferae with special reference to the development of thyloses and their correlation with the thylosal strands of the pteridophytes.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Although the question as to the Span of Attention has occupied the minds of psychologists for years, it cannot be said that all difference of opinion in regard to it has been removed. There are still, on the one hand, those who maintain that attention can be given to several objects at the same time, and, on the other hand, those who claim that this is impossible, and that instead of being distributed, attention oscillates between the several objects in the field of attentions. [...]
thesis.creator: MacKenzie, John M.
thesis.subject: Psychology.
thesis.title: The span of attention.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Few things have been more lovely in the marvellous English poetry of the last three centuries than its pictures of the fairy world, real to our ancestors. So persistent was the fairy note throughout the evolution of our literature, that from Shakespeare, Drayton and Herrick, to Swinburne, Tennyson and Rossetti the tribute to the elfin realm was paid, and to-day in Ireland and Gaelic Scotland the horns of Elfland still blow "of perilous seas in faery lands forlorn." [...]
thesis.creator: Macnaughton, Ariel M.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: The evolution of the fairy world, with special reference to its treatment in English literature.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The lodestone which, as early as the fifteenth century, drew the most daring and enterprising spirits of the civilized world to Africa, was ever the unbounded mineral wealth of that country, so ably narrated in the tales of King Solomon's Mines, the jewels and gold of the Queen of Sheba, and the traditional "gold of Ophir". [...]

thesis.description: Given any algebraic equation f(x, y) = 0 connecting two variables X and y, the aggregate of the pairs of values (x,y) which satisfy this equation constitute an Algebraic Configuration. Every pair of values (x,y) defines a point or place of the configuration. [...]
